questiontext.text:
Exercise

A graph of the function \(y={@y@}\) for \(x\) between \({@low@}\) and \({@upp@}\) is shown in the diagram. The graph is rotated around the \(x\)-axis to produce the solid shown. Find its volume.


The solid of revolution is divided into a number of thin circular discs.

As in the previous Task, the solid is considered to be composed of lots of circular discs of radius \(y\), (which in this example is equal to \({@y@}\)), and thickness \(\delta x\).


Write down the volume of each disc. You can type \(\delta x\) as deltax.

\(\quad V_{\mbox{disc}}=\) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]


Write down the expression which represents summing the volumes of all such discs:

\(x=\) [[input:ans4up]] [[validation:ans4up]]
\(\displaystyle \sum\) [[input:ans4sum]] [[validation:ans4sum]]
\(x=\) [[input:ans4dn]] [[validation:ans4dn]]

[[feedback:prt4]]


Write down the integral which results from taking the limit of the sum as \(\delta x \rightarrow 0\):

\(\displaystyle \int\)
[[input:ans2up]] [[validation:ans2up]]
[[input:ans2dn]] [[validation:ans2dn]]
[[input:ans2int]] [[validation:ans2int]] \(\mathrm{d}x\)

[[feedback:prt2]]


Perform the integration to find the volume of the solid:

\(\quad V =\) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

A disc is like a cylinder. So the volume of the disc will be given by the area of the circle 'base', which has radius \({@y@}\), multiplied by the thickness of the disc, \(\delta x\), so that \[V_{\mbox{disc}} = {@ta1@}.\]

Summing all such disks that exist between \(x={@low@}\) and \(x={@upp@}\) can be written as \[\sum_{x={@low@}}^{x={@upp@}} {@ta4sum@}.\]

The integral corresponding to the limit given is \[\int_{@ta2dn@}^{@ta2up@} {@ta2int@} \,\mathrm{d}x.\]

Evaluating that integral, we obtain the volume of the cone: \[V={@ta3@}.\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
